This setting can have a value from 3600 (1 hour) to 43200 (12 hours).

secret_format.description:
A jinja2 templated object to define the shape of the secret to be created in Secrets
Manager instead of copying the vault secret as is.

assume_condition.description: condition context keys for IAM and AWS STS

assume_action.description: alternate sts call instead of AssumeRole

role_policy.description: a policy to be created and attached to the role

grafana_datasource.description: is rds instance used as a grafana datasource

delete.description: Flag a resource to be deleted
Flag a resource to be deleted
Flag a resource to be deleted
Flag a resource to be deleted
Flag a resource to be deleted

ingress_cidr_blocks.description: ingress cidr blocks to allow for an alb

secret_format.description:
A jinja2 templated object to define the shape of the secret to be created in Secrets
Manager instead of copying the vault secret as is.

tag_name.description: name of tag to use to correlate AMI ID to commit

upstream.description: jenkins instance and job to wait for

name.description: name of jenkins job to wait for
base fqdn of the zone

delete.description: Flag a resource to be deleted

/aws/terraform-resource-lifecycle-1.yml.description: meta-arguments available for all resource blocks regardless of type

create_before_destroy.description: create replacement object before the prior object is destroyed

prevent_destroy.description: reject with an error any plan that would destroy the object

ignore_changes.description: attributes to ignore when planning updates to the object

cidr_block.description: Reference to a network reservation file

availability_zones.description: A list of availability zones names in the region.

/cloudflare/account-1.yml.title: Account
/cloudflare/account-1.yml.description:
Schema for defining a Cloudflare account managed via app-interface.
This schema captures all metadata, configuration, credentials, and
ownership information required to manage Cloudflare accounts in a
declarative and automated way. It supports integration with Terraform,
secure credential management, and compliance requirements such as
two-factor enforcement and deletion approvals.

name.description:
The unique name of the Cloudflare account. Used to identify the
account across the system and in automation.

description.description:
A human-readable description of the Cloudflare account, its
intended use, or any relevant context.

providerVersion.description:
The version of the Cloudflare provider used for managing this
account. This is important for ensuring compatibility with
automation tools such as Terraform.

accountOwners.description:
A list of individuals or teams responsible for this Cloudflare
account. Each entry must include a name and email address for
contact and accountability.

name.description: The name of the account owner.

email.description: The email address of the account owner.

apiCredentials.description:
Reference to the Vault secret containing the API credentials for
this Cloudflare account. Used by automation and integrations to
securely access the Cloudflare API.

enforceTwofactor.description:
If true, enforces two-factor authentication for all users in this
Cloudflare account to meet security and compliance requirements.

type.description:
The type of Cloudflare account. Use 'standard' for regular accounts
or 'enterprise' for accounts with enterprise features and support.

terraformStateAccount.description:
Reference to the AWS account used for storing Terraform state in S3.
This enables stateful infrastructure management for Cloudflare
resources.

deletionApprovals.description:
A list of deletion approvals required for this Cloudflare account.
Each entry references a deletion approval object, ensuring that
destructive actions are reviewed and authorized.

/cloudflare/dns-record-1.yml.title: DNS Record
/cloudflare/dns-record-1.yml.description:
Schema for defining a DNS record in a Cloudflare-managed zone.
This schema supports all standard DNS record types, including
A, AAAA, CNAME, TXT, NS, MX, CAA, DS, and DNSKEY. It enables
declarative management of DNS records, including advanced DNSSEC
and proxying options, for automation and compliance in
app-interface-managed Cloudflare zones.

identifier.description:
The unique identifier for this DNS record. Used to reference
and manage the record within app-interface and automation.

name.description:
The DNS name for this record (e.g., 'www.example.com').
This is the hostname or subdomain to which the record applies.

type.description:
The DNS record type. Supported types include A, AAAA, CAA,
CNAME, TXT, NS, MX, DS (for DNSSEC signing key), and DNSKEY
(for DNSSEC key records).

ttl.description:
The time-to-live (TTL) for this DNS record, in seconds.
Determines how long the record is cached by resolvers.

value.description:
The value for this DNS record. For most record types, this
is the target hostname, IP address, or record data.

data.description:
Additional data for advanced DNS record types, such as DS
and DNSKEY records for DNSSEC. Includes algorithm, key tag,
flags, protocol, public key, digest type, digest, tag, and value.

algorithm.description: The algorithm used for DNSSEC records (DS/DNSKEY).

key_tag.description: The key tag for DNSSEC records.

flags.description: The flags field for DNSKEY records.

protocol.description: The protocol field for DNSKEY records.

public_key.description: The public key for DNSKEY records.

digest_type.description: The digest type for DS records.

digest.description: The digest value for DS records.

proxied.description:
If true, enables Cloudflare proxying for this DNS record.
Only applicable to certain record types (e.g., A, AAAA, CNAME).

priority.description: The priority for MX records. Lower values indicate higher priority.

/cloudflare/dns-zone-1.yml.title: DNS Zone
/cloudflare/dns-zone-1.yml.description:
Schema for defining a Cloudflare DNS zone managed via app-interface.
This schema enables declarative management of DNS zones, including
zone metadata, plan type, account association, and DNS records.
It supports automation, compliance, and integration with Cloudflare
APIs, and allows for advanced configuration such as partial zones,
record limits, and zone deletion.

identifier.description:
The unique identifier for this DNS zone. Used to reference and
manage the zone within app-interface and automation.

zone.description:
The DNS zone name (e.g., 'example.com'). This is the root domain
managed by Cloudflare.

plan.description:
The Cloudflare plan type for this zone. Use 'free' for standard
zones or 'enterprise' for zones with enterprise features and support.

type.description:
The type of DNS zone. 'full' zones are fully managed by Cloudflare,
while 'partial' zones are partially delegated.

account.description: Reference to the Cloudflare account that owns this DNS zone.

records.description:
A list of DNS records to manage within this zone. Supports all
standard record types and advanced DNSSEC options.

max_records.description:
The maximum number of DNS records allowed in this zone. Used to
enforce record limits and prevent accidental over-provisioning.

delete.description:
If true, marks this DNS zone for deletion. Used to automate
cleanup and deprovisioning of zones in Cloudflare.

/dependencies/acs-instance-1.yml.title: ACS Instance
/dependencies/acs-instance-1.yml.description:
Schema for referencing an Advanced Cluster Security (ACS) instance as a dependency.
This schema enables app-interface to reference ACS instances for integration and
configuration purposes. It does not provision or manage the lifecycle of the ACS
instance itself. Use this schema to declare connection details, credentials, and
authentication provider configuration for ACS integrations.

name.description:
The unique name of the ACS instance. Used to identify and reference
this instance in app-interface and related integrations.

description.description:
A human-readable description of the ACS instance, its environment,
or any relevant operational context.

url.description:
The URL of the ACS API endpoint. Used by integrations and automation
to connect to the ACS instance.

credentials.description:
Reference to the Vault secret containing the credentials required to
authenticate to this ACS instance.

authProvider.description:
Configuration for the authentication provider used by this ACS instance.
Supports OIDC and other provider types for integration and access control.

name.description: The name of the authentication provider configured for this ACS instance.

id.description: The unique identifier of the authentication provider.

kind.description: The kind of authentication provider. Currently supports 'oidc'.

/dependencies/container-image-mirror-1.y.title: Container Image Mirror
/dependencies/container-image-mirror-1.y.description:
Schema for referencing a container image mirror as a dependency.
This schema allows app-interface to declare external container image
mirrors for use in automation and deployment workflows. It does not
provision or manage the lifecycle of the mirror itself. Use this schema
to specify the mirror URL, credentials, and tag filtering for integration.

url.description:
The URL of the container image mirror. This is the registry or
repository endpoint from which images can be pulled.

pullCredentials.description:
Reference to the Vault secret containing credentials required to
pull images from this mirror. Used for authentication to private
or restricted mirrors.

tags.description:
A list of image tags to include from this mirror. Only images
matching these tags will be considered for use.

tagsExclude.description:
A list of image tags to exclude from this mirror. Images matching
these tags will be ignored, even if included by the 'tags' field.

/dependencies/dependency-1.yml.title: Dependency
/dependencies/dependency-1.yml.description:
Schema for referencing an external or internal dependency in app-interface.
This schema enables teams to declare dependencies for integration, monitoring,
and documentation purposes. It does not provision or manage the lifecycle of
the dependency itself. Use this schema to describe the dependency's name,
operational model, statefulness, SLA, monitoring, and failure impact.

name.description:
The unique name of the dependency. Used to identify and reference
this dependency in app-interface and related integrations.

description.description:
A human-readable description of the dependency, its purpose,
or any relevant operational context.

statefulness.description:
The statefulness classification of the dependency. 'Durable' indicates
persistent state, 'Cache' indicates ephemeral state, and 'Stateless'
indicates no state is maintained.

opsModel.description:
The operational model for the dependency. 'Hosted' means managed by a
third party, 'External' means outside the organization, and 'Internal'
means managed within the organization.

statusPage.description:
The URL of the status page for this dependency, if available. Used for
monitoring uptime and incident reporting.

SLA.description:
The service level agreement (SLA) for this dependency. Defines the
expected reliability, uptime, and support commitments.

dependencyFailureImpact.description:
The impact on your service if this dependency fails. Used for risk
assessment and incident response planning.

monitoring.description:
Monitoring configuration for this dependency. Supports specifying a
direct monitoring URL or referencing an OpenShift namespace and
resource for monitoring integration.

url.description: The direct URL to the monitoring dashboard or endpoint for this dependency.

namespace.description:
Reference to the OpenShift namespace where monitoring resources for
this dependency are located.

provider.description:
The provider type for monitoring. 'resource' for direct resource
monitoring, 'resource-template' for template-based monitoring.

path.description: The path to the monitoring resource or template.

_target_namespace_zone.description: a namespace and a route53 zone name provisioned within that namespace

allowed_vault_secret_paths.description: List of paths used to limit the secrets that can be accessed for creating DNS records, the primary use case being domain control validation (DCV)

environmentUrl.description: The URL to a specific Dynatrace entity called environment, which is also known as tenant.

bootstrapToken.description: Dynatrace API token dedicated for generating new API tokens for Hypershift.

environment.description: Which of integration, stage or production are the data coming from.

awsRegion.description: A list of HCP AWS regions.

/dependencies/endpoint-monitoring-provid.title: Endpoint Monitoring Provider
/dependencies/endpoint-monitoring-provid.description:
Schema for referencing an endpoint monitoring provider as a dependency in app-interface.
This schema enables teams to declare monitoring providers for endpoints, supporting
integration with blackbox-exporter and signalfx. Use this schema to specify provider type,
check intervals, timeouts, metric labels, and provider-specific configuration for
endpoint monitoring automation and observability.

name.description:
The unique name of the endpoint monitoring provider. Used to identify and
reference this provider in app-interface and related integrations.

description.description:
A human-readable description of the endpoint monitoring provider, its
purpose, or any relevant operational context.

provider.description:
The provider defines which monitoring implementation will be used for endpoints.
Supported values are 'blackbox-exporter' and 'signalfx'.

timeout.description:
Timeout for the monitoring check (e.g., '10s', '5m'). Specifies how long
to wait for a check to complete before considering it failed.

checkInterval.description:
Interval between endpoint checks (e.g., '10s', '1m'). Determines how
frequently the monitoring provider will check the endpoint.

metricLabels.description:
Labels to be added to the resulting Prometheus metrics. Used for
categorization and filtering of metrics in observability systems.

blackboxExporter.description:
Configuration options specific to the blackbox-exporter provider.
Used when 'provider' is set to 'blackbox-exporter'.

module.description:
The blackbox exporter module to use for the endpoint check (e.g., 'http_2xx').
Modules define the type of probe and protocol to use.

namespace.description: Reference to the namespace where the Prometheus Probe CR will be created.

exporterUrl.description:
The blackbox-exporter URL to use. Must be a full scrape URL accessible
by the monitoring system.

signalFx.description:
Configuration options specific to the signalfx provider.
Used when 'provider' is set to 'signalfx'.

namespace.description: Reference to the namespace where the Prometheus Probe CR will be created.

exporterUrl.description:
The signalfx-prometheus-exporter URL to use. Must be a full scrape URL
accessible by the monitoring system.

targetFilterLabel.description: The signalfx label that holds the target value to be filtered on.

name.description: The name of the feature toggle

description.description: A description of the feature toggle

delete.description: Whether to delete the feature toggle

unleash.description: Configuration for an Unleash feature toggle

type.description: The type of the feature toggle. Default is "release"

projects.description: The projects that the feature toggle is associated with

provider.description: The provider of the feature toggle

unleash.description: Configuration for an Unleash feature toggle

type.description: The type of the feature toggle. Default is "release"

projects.description: The projects that the feature toggle is associated with

eventThrottleRate.description: Percentage of new events to deny. 0-100

identifier.description: ASG used for this Jenkins cloud, need to match an ASG identifier.

credentialsId.description: Jenkins credential name of ssh private key to be used for logging in to the remote host.

jvmOptions.description: JAVA Options to set in the agents

name.description: The Jira field name as shown in the UI

value.description: The value to set the field to as a string as shown in the UI

/dependencies/jira-severity-priority-map.description: mappings between alert severities and jira ticket priorities

items.description: a mapping between an alert severity to a ticket priority

name.description: Name of the repository to filter.

tags.description:
This limits which tags to mirror to the ones in the list.
They will take preference over the ones excluded.
Regular expressions are supported.

tagsExclude.description: Tags to exclude. Regular expression are supported.

status.description:
a list of providers that can influence the status of this
status page component

prometheusAlerts.description: config options for the 'prometheus-alerts' status provider

matchers.description:
a list of prometheus alert matchers (alertname and labels) and a
corresponding status that should be applied to a component if such
a metric was found

alert.description: the alert name to match on

labels.description: the alert labels to match on

componentStatus.description:
the status to apply to the status page component if this a
matching prometheus alert was found

manual.description: config options for the 'manual' status provider

componentStatus.description: the status to apply to the status page component

from.description: an optional start date to activate this provider

until.description: an optional start date to deactivate this provider

integrations.description: holds information which bucket key stores the terraform state per integration

name.description: The name of the project. For open-source Unleash it must be "default"!

Name used in the Dynatrace API as prefix for token.
Note, that due to Dynatrace API the token name length is limited.

keyNameInSecret.description: Key for this token inside the openshift secret object. If not set, uses "name"

outputs_secret_image.description: Docker image to use for the outputs secret container

outputs_secret_version.description: Version of the outputs secret container to use

outputs_secret_image.description: Docker image to use for the outputs secret container

outputs_secret_version.description: Version of the outputs secret container to use

outputs_secret_image.description: Docker image to use for the outputs secret container

outputs_secret_version.description: Version of the outputs secret container to use

default_tags.description: Default tags to apply to all managed external resources.

name.description: base fqdn of the zone

enableDeadMansSnitch.description: Flag to automate snitch creation/deletion by deadmanssnitch integration

enableCostReport.description: Flag to enable openshift cost report

private.description: kube API (load balancer) and router is private, access require peering

subnet_ids.description: Hosted Clusters only: list of subnet_ids to use with the cluster creation.

availability_zones.description: Hosted Clusters only: list of availability_zones to use with the cluster creation.

fips.description: Create cluster that uses FIPS Validated / Modules in Process cryptographic libraries.

allowPrivateHcpApiAccess.description:
if set to true, enable traffic from attached TGW to reach the API and oauth server
of a private HCP by adapting the VPC endpoint security group

manageAccountRoutes.description:
historically, account-vpc did not have support for managing routes on the aws side.
instead of re-using manageRoutes, this is a backwards compatible field for managing such routes.
once all account-vpc connections that have manageRoutes also have manageAccountRoutes,
we can consolidate to use managedRoutes only.

cidrBlocks.description: the list of cidr blocks to route through this transit gateway

clusterAdmin.description: should enable cluster admin for this cluster

internal.description: the cluster is attached to the transit gateway to the VPN, only private cluster can be internal

dtp.description: request dynatrace-token-provider to issue a token for the cluster

tenant.description: dynatrace tenant id to issue tokens for

token-spec.description: name of the DTP token-spec to use for this cluster

mutexes.description:
list of named upgrade mutex locks for this cluster. A cluster needs
to acquire all its mutex locks in order to be upgraded. A mutex lock
can be held by only one cluster at a time.

sector.description:
The sector which the cluster is part of. Sector dependencies are
defined in openshift-cluster-manager-1.yml. A cluster will be
upgraded to a version only if clusters in previous sectors are
running that version or higher.

blockedVersions.description:
List of versions that will be rejected for upgrades.
They can be regular expressions"

/openshift/deploy-resources-1.yml.description: CPU and memory resources used in openshift objects

dryRunLabelSynchronization.description:
Disable the synchronization of labels from the subscription to the cluster.
This is useful if you want to let fleet labeler render the inventory first and
investigate/change any desired labels manually before the synchronization starts.

labelDefaults.description: List of default labels to apply to clusters by external configuration labels

clusters.description: List of clusters to define dynatrace token provider labels for

name.description: cluster name

/openshift/lean-namespace-1.yml.description: a lean definition of a namespace in a cluster with an automation token and some context in the form of an environment

managedExternalResources.description: are external resources managed for this namespace

externalResources.description: external resources to provision for this namespace

The internal OCM organization ID that can be found via
ocm whoami | jq .organization.id

externalOrgId.description:

addonUpgradeTests.description: trigger a job in jenkins following an addon upgrade

highest.description: highest version currently running that workload

blockedVersions.description: List of versions that will be rejected for upgrades. They can be regular expressions

upgradePolicyAllowedWorkloads.description: List of workloads that are allowed to be defined as cluster upgrade policy workload

upgradePolicyAllowedMutexes.description: List of mutexes that are allowed to be defined as cluster upgrade policy mutex

ausClusterHealthChecks.description: List of cluster health check providers

sectors.description: List of allowed deployment sectors and their dependencies

maxParallelUpgrades.description:
The maximum number of upgrades that can happen at any given time within that sector.
This string must contain an bare integer or percentage of the number of clusters in the sector.
Default is "100%", so any number of parallel upgrades is allowed.

upgradePolicyClusters.description: List of clusters to define upgrade policies for (no cluster management in such OCM orgs)

inheritVersionData.description: list of OCM organizations from which we will retrieve cluster version informations (current versions stats, soak days, sectors, ..).

publishVersionData.description: list of OCM organizations to which we will publish cluster version informations (current versions stats, soak days, sectors, ..)

CPU and memory resources requirements to be set in pods requests
configuration

the provider defines the method of formatting the terraform output
into a secret. a provider can declare additional configuration data to
get the job done or define the format directly

data.description:
the data to use for the secret. the field values can use the

/vault-config/audit-1.yml.title: Audit
/vault-config/audit-1.yml.description:
Schema for configuring a Vault audit device. Vault audit devices record
all requests and responses to Vault, providing a detailed audit trail for
security and compliance. This schema supports configuration of file, syslog,
and socket audit backends, allowing teams to specify device type, options,
and integration with Vault instances. Use this schema to ensure all Vault
operations are logged according to organizational and regulatory requirements.

_path.description:
The mount path for the audit device in Vault. Must end with a slash.
This determines where the audit device is enabled and how logs are
referenced in Vault.

type.description:
The type of audit device to enable. Supported types are 'file' for
writing logs to disk, 'syslog' for sending logs to the system logger,
and 'socket' for streaming logs to a network socket.

instance.description: Reference to the Vault instance where this audit device will be enabled.

description.description:
A human-readable description of the audit device configuration, its
purpose, or any relevant operational context.

options.description:
Configuration options specific to the audit device type. These options
control how and where audit logs are written, their format, and other
backend-specific settings. Refer to the Vault audit device documentation
for details on each option.

_type.description: The backend type for this audit device. Must be 'file' for file-based audit logging.

file_path.description:
The path to the file where audit logs will be written. Ensure the
Vault process has write permissions to this file.

log_raw.description:
If 'true', logs the raw request and response data. If 'false',
sensitive information is redacted.

hmac_accessor.description:
If 'true', includes the accessor in the HMAC of sensitive values
for easier correlation.

mode.description:
The file mode (permissions) to set on the audit log file, specified
as an octal string (e.g., '0640').

format.description:
The output format for audit logs. 'json' selects JSON format,
and 'jsonx' selects XML format.

prefix.description:
A string to prefix to each log line, useful for log filtering or
identification.

/vault-config/auth-1.yml.title: Auth
/vault-config/auth-1.yml.description:
Schema for configuring a Vault authentication method. Vault auth methods
enable users, applications, and systems to authenticate and obtain tokens
for accessing secrets and APIs. This schema supports configuration of
multiple auth backends, including AppRole, GitHub, OIDC, and Kubernetes,
and allows specifying backend-specific settings, policy mappings, and
integration with Vault instances. Use this schema to ensure secure,
auditable, and flexible authentication to Vault in accordance with
organizational and regulatory requirements.

_path.description:
The mount path for the auth method in Vault. Must end with a slash.
Determines where the auth backend is enabled and how it is referenced.

type.description:
The type of Vault auth method to enable. Supported types include:
  - 'approle': Machine-to-machine authentication using AppRole IDs and secrets.
  - 'github': User authentication via GitHub organizations and teams.
  - 'oidc': User authentication via OpenID Connect providers.
  - 'kubernetes': Service account authentication from Kubernetes clusters.

instance.description: Reference to the Vault instance where this auth method will be enabled.

description.description:
A human-readable description of the auth method configuration, its
purpose, or any relevant operational context.

settings.description:
Backend-specific configuration for the auth method. Each auth type
supports different settings, such as OIDC discovery URLs, GitHub
organizations, or Kubernetes API endpoints. Refer to the Vault
documentation for details on each backend's configuration options.

kubernetes_host.description: The host URL of the Kubernetes API server to authenticate against.

kubernetes_ca_cert.description: Reference to the Vault secret containing the Kubernetes CA certificate.

kubernetes_ca_cert_kv_version.description: The Vault KV version for the CA certificate secret.

disable_local_ca_jwt.description: If true, disables using the local CA JWT for authentication.

organization.description: The GitHub organization to use for authentication.

base_url.description: The base URL for GitHub Enterprise, or leave blank for github.com.

max_ttl.description: The maximum TTL for tokens issued by this auth method.

ttl.description: The default TTL for tokens issued by this auth method.

default_role.description: The default role to use for OIDC authentication.

oidc_discovery_url.description: The OIDC discovery URL for the identity provider.

oidc_client_id.description: The client ID for OIDC authentication.

oidc_client_secret.description: Reference to the Vault secret containing the OIDC client secret.

oidc_client_secret_kv_version.description: The Vault KV version for the OIDC client secret.

policy_mappings.description:
A list of mappings from external identity groups (such as GitHub teams)
to Vault policies. Each mapping specifies the external group and the
Vault policies to assign upon successful authentication. This enables
fine-grained access control and policy assignment based on identity
provider attributes.

github_team.description: Reference to the GitHub team used for mapping to Vault policies.

policies.description:
A list of Vault policies to assign to users authenticated via this
external group.

/vault-config/instance-1.yml.title: Vault Instance
/vault-config/instance-1.yml.description:
Schema for defining a Vault instance managed by app-interface and vault-manager.
This schema enables configuration of multiple Vault clusters, supporting
environments with more than one Vault deployment. Each instance specifies
connection details, authentication, and operational metadata, allowing
vault-manager to manage audit devices, auth methods, policies, and secrets
for each Vault instance independently.

name.description:
The unique name of the Vault instance. Used to reference this instance
from other Vault configuration objects.

description.description:
A human-readable description of the Vault instance, its environment,
or any relevant operational context.

address.description:
The base URL or address of the Vault API endpoint for this instance.
Used by vault-manager and integrations to connect to the Vault cluster.

auth.description:
Reference to the authentication configuration for this Vault instance.
Specifies how vault-manager and integrations authenticate to this Vault
cluster, such as using a token or AppRole credentials.

replication.description:
A list of replication configurations for this Vault instance. Used to
define replication relationships (such as primary/secondary) between
Vault clusters for high availability and disaster recovery.

/vault-config/instance-auth-1.yml.title: Vault Instance Auth
/vault-config/instance-auth-1.yml.description:
Schema for defining authentication configuration for a Vault instance.
This schema supports multiple authentication providers, such as AppRole
and token-based authentication, and allows specifying the secret engine
version and required credentials. Use this schema to securely configure
how vault-manager and integrations authenticate to each Vault cluster.

provider.description:
The authentication provider to use for this Vault instance.
Supported values are 'approle' for AppRole-based authentication
and 'token' for token-based authentication.

kubeRoleName.description:
The name of the Kubernetes role to use for authentication, if
applicable. Used when integrating Vault with Kubernetes service
accounts.

secretEngine.description:
The version of the Vault KV secret engine to use for storing and
retrieving secrets. Must be either 'kv_v1' or 'kv_v2'.

roleID.description:
Reference to the Vault secret containing the AppRole RoleID.
Required when using the 'approle' provider.

secretID.description:
Reference to the Vault secret containing the AppRole SecretID.
Required when using the 'approle' provider.

token.description:
Reference to the Vault secret containing the authentication token.
Required when using the 'token' provider.

/vault-config/policy-1.yml.title: Policy
/vault-config/policy-1.yml.description:
Schema for defining a Vault policy. Vault policies specify access control
rules for secrets, paths, and operations within a Vault instance. This
schema enables teams to manage policies declaratively, associating them
with specific Vault instances and providing fine-grained permissions for
users, applications, and integrations. Policies are written in HCL and
control what actions are allowed or denied within Vault.

name.description:
The unique name of the Vault policy. Used to identify and reference
this policy within the Vault instance and app-interface.

instance.description:
Reference to the Vault instance where this policy will be applied.
This enables management of policies across multiple Vault clusters.

rules.description:
The policy rules written in HCL (HashiCorp Configuration Language).
These rules define the allowed and denied actions for paths and
operations in Vault. Refer to the Vault documentation for policy
syntax and examples.

/vault-config/replication-1.yml.title: Replication
/vault-config/replication-1.yml.description:
Schema for defining Vault replication configuration. Replication enables
secrets and data to be synchronized between multiple Vault instances,
supporting high availability, disaster recovery, and multi-region
deployments. This schema allows specifying the source and destination
authentication, the Vault instance, and the paths to replicate.

vaultInstance.description:
Reference to the Vault instance participating in replication.
This is the target instance where replicated data will be managed.

destAuth.description:
Authentication configuration for the destination Vault instance.
Specifies how to authenticate when writing replicated data.

sourceAuth.description:
Authentication configuration for the source Vault instance.
Specifies how to authenticate when reading data to replicate.

paths.description:
A list of paths to replicate between Vault instances. Each entry
specifies a path and its replication configuration.

/vault-config/replication-paths-1.yml.title: Replication Paths
/vault-config/replication-paths-1.yml.description:
Schema for defining replication paths for Vault replication. Replication
paths specify which secrets or data should be synchronized between Vault
instances, and how access is managed for each path. This schema supports
integration with Jenkins instances and Vault policies, enabling fine-grained
control over which secrets are replicated and under what conditions.

provider.description:
The provider type for this replication path. Supported values are
'jenkins' for Jenkins integration and 'policy' for policy-based
replication.

jenkinsInstance.description:
Reference to the Jenkins instance associated with this replication
path. Required when the provider is 'jenkins'.

policy.description:
Reference to the Vault policy that governs access to this replication
path. Required for both 'jenkins' and 'policy' providers.

/vault-config/role-1.yml.title: Role
/vault-config/role-1.yml.description:
Schema for defining a Vault role. Vault roles are used to configure
authentication and authorization for users, applications, or services
accessing secrets in Vault. This schema supports multiple auth backends
(AppRole, OIDC, Kubernetes), allows specifying policies, token settings,
and advanced options for fine-grained access control. Roles are associated
with a specific Vault instance and mount, and can be customized for
different use cases and security requirements.

name.description:
The unique name of the Vault role. Used to identify and reference
this role within the Vault instance and app-interface.

mount.description:
Reference to the Vault auth mount where this role is defined.
Specifies the authentication backend (e.g., approle, oidc, kubernetes).

type.description:
The type of Vault role. Indicates the authentication backend
(e.g., approle, oidc, kubernetes) this role is associated with.

instance.description:
Reference to the Vault instance where this role will be created.
Enables management of roles across multiple Vault clusters.

output_path.description:
The output path for generated credentials or tokens, if applicable.
Used for integrations that need to consume credentials from Vault.

options.description:
Configuration options specific to the role type and authentication
backend. Includes policy assignments, token settings, and advanced
options for AppRole, OIDC, and Kubernetes roles. Refer to the Vault
documentation for details on each backend's role configuration.

policies.description:
A list of Vault policies to attach to this role. Policies define
the permissions granted to tokens issued for this role.

token_policies.description: Additional policies to attach to tokens issued by this role.

bind_secret_id.description: If 'true', a SecretID must be presented when logging in with this role.

local_secret_ids.description: If 'true', SecretIDs are scoped to the local cluster only.

token_period.description: The period, in seconds, for which the issued token is valid.

secret_id_num_uses.description: The number of times a SecretID can be used before it is invalidated.

secret_id_ttl.description: The time-to-live (TTL) for SecretIDs, in seconds.

token_explicit_max_ttl.description: The explicit maximum TTL for tokens issued by this role.

token_max_ttl.description: The maximum TTL for tokens issued by this role.

token_no_default_policy.description: If true, tokens will not have the default policy attached.

token_num_uses.description: The number of times a token can be used before it is revoked.

token_ttl.description: The default TTL for tokens issued by this role.

token_type.description: The type of token to issue (e.g., service, batch).

token_policies.description: Additional policies to attach to tokens issued by this role.

policies.description: Policies to attach to this role.

secret_id_bound_cidrs.description: A list of CIDR blocks that SecretIDs must originate from.

token_bound_cidrs.description: A list of CIDR blocks that tokens must originate from.

allowed_redirect_uris.description: A list of allowed redirect URIs for OIDC authentication.

bound_audiences.description: A list of audiences that tokens must be bound to.

bound_claims.description: Claims that must be present in the OIDC token.

bound_claims_type.description: The type of claim matching to use.

bound_subject.description: The subject that tokens must be bound to.

claim_mappings.description: Mappings from OIDC claims to Vault identity attributes.

clock_skew_leeway.description: The allowed clock skew, in seconds, for validating tokens.

expiration_leeway.description: The allowed expiration leeway, in seconds, for validating tokens.

groups_claim.description: The claim in the OIDC token that contains group information.

max_age.description: The maximum age of the token, in seconds.

not_before_leeway.description: The allowed not-before leeway, in seconds, for validating tokens.

oidc_scopes.description: A list of OIDC scopes to request.

role_type.description: The type of role for OIDC/JWT authentication.

token_ttl.description: The default TTL for tokens issued by this role.

token_max_ttl.description: The maximum TTL for tokens issued by this role.

token_explicit_max_ttl.description: The explicit maximum TTL for tokens issued by this role.

token_type.description: The type of token to issue (e.g., service, batch).

token_period.description: The period, in seconds, for which the issued token is valid.

token_policies.description: Additional policies to attach to tokens issued by this role.

token_bound_cidrs.description: A list of CIDR blocks that tokens must originate from.

token_no_default_policy.description: If true, tokens will not have the default policy attached.

token_num_uses.description: The number of times a token can be used before it is revoked.

user_claim.description: The claim in the OIDC token that identifies the user.

verbose_oidc_logging.description: If true, enables verbose logging for OIDC authentication.

alias_name_source.description: The source for alias names in Kubernetes authentication.

audience.description: The audience to use for Kubernetes service account tokens.

bound_service_account_names.description: A list of Kubernetes service account names that can use this role.

bound_service_account_namespaces.description: A list of Kubernetes namespaces for the bound service accounts.

token_ttl.description: The default TTL for tokens issued by this role.

token_max_ttl.description: The maximum TTL for tokens issued by this role.

token_explicit_max_ttl.description: The explicit maximum TTL for tokens issued by this role.

token_type.description: The type of token to issue (e.g., service, batch).

token_period.description: The period, in seconds, for which the issued token is valid.

token_policies.description: Additional policies to attach to tokens issued by this role.

token_bound_cidrs.description: A list of CIDR blocks that tokens must originate from.

token_no_default_policy.description: If true, tokens will not have the default policy attached.

token_num_uses.description: The number of times a token can be used before it is revoked.

/vault-config/secret-engine-1.yml.title: Secret Engine
/vault-config/secret-engine-1.yml.description:
Schema for defining a Vault secret engine. Secret engines are components
in Vault that store, generate, or encrypt data, such as key-value (kv)
stores or TOTP generators. This schema allows configuring the mount path,
engine type, Vault instance, and backend-specific options. Use this schema
to declaratively manage secret engines across multiple Vault clusters.

_path.description:
The mount path for the secret engine in Vault. Must end with a slash.
Determines where the engine is enabled and how it is referenced.

type.description:
The type of secret engine to enable. Supported types are 'kv' for
key-value secrets and 'totp' for time-based one-time password generators.

instance.description:
Reference to the Vault instance where this secret engine will be enabled.
Enables management of secret engines across multiple Vault clusters.

description.description:
A human-readable description of the secret engine, its purpose, or
any relevant operational context.

options.description:
Backend-specific configuration options for the secret engine. For 'kv'
engines, this includes the version (v1 or v2). Refer to the Vault
documentation for details on each engine's options.

version.description:
The version of the key-value secret engine. Use '1' for kv v1,
or '2' for kv v2, which supports versioned secrets.

state.description: List items must never be removed. To signal that a list item should be deleted the state should be set to deleted and downstream integrations will remove the corresponding object if it exists.

statusPageStatus.description: a list of supported status page component status

dhmsDuration.description: The format is a subset of Go's ParseDuration format, only allowing from days to seconds in resolution, e.g. '1h', '1d1h1m2s', ...

path.description: A path is a string that starts with a forward slash and contains only alphanumeric characters, hyphens, spaces, and underscores. It does not end with a slash.

date.description: A date is a string in the format YYYY-MM-DD.

/metaschema-1.json.description: Defines the structure of a qontract-schema

externalDocumentation.description: Link(s) to external documentation for this schema
